text: What’s the fastest package to plot big graphs? The `loadsnap(:facebook_combined)` graph with ~4000 nodes and ~90 000 edges takes about 50 seconds with `GraphPlot`. Is that reasonable, or am I missing out on something?

elements.text: What’s the fastest package to plot big graphs? The
loadsnap(:facebook_combined)
graph with ~4000 nodes and ~90 000 edges takes about 50 seconds with
GraphPlot
. Is that reasonable, or am I missing out on something?

text: The bottleneck here seems to be the default spring layout

elements.text: The bottleneck here seems to be the default spring layout

text:
```julia> @time gplot(g)
 60.720307 seconds (465.68 k allocations: 30.918 MiB, 0.05% gc time, 0.14% compilation time)


julia> @time gplot(g, layout=random_layout)
  0.056487 seconds (461.01 k allocations: 26.251 MiB)```

elements.text:
julia> @time gplot(g)
 60.720307 seconds (465.68 k allocations: 30.918 MiB, 0.05% gc time, 0.14% compilation time)


julia> @time gplot(g, layout=random_layout)
  0.056487 seconds (461.01 k allocations: 26.251 MiB)

text: so if you would use another layout, or provide your own coordinates, then it would certainly be faster

elements.text: so if you would use another layout, or provide your own coordinates, then it would certainly be faster

text: GraphRecipes will probly be even slower (last time I checked, they still allocate an adjacency matrix) and VegaGraphs uses the same layout algorithms as GraphPlots, as fasr as I know

elements.text: GraphRecipes will probly be even slower (last time I checked, they still allocate an adjacency matrix) and VegaGraphs uses the same layout algorithms as GraphPlots, as fasr as I know

text: to be honest, I am not sure of any of the layout algorithms that we currently have in Julia will produce anything that is fast and nice looking

elements.text: to be honest, I am not sure of any of the layout algorithms that we currently have in Julia will produce anything that is fast and nice looking

text: I also don't know if that is even possible with that graph

elements.text: I also don't know if that is even possible with that graph
thanks!

text: best option would probably be to export to .gz (formally know as dot) format and then use graphvviz to plot

elements.text: best option would probably be to export to .gz (formally know as dot) format and then use graphvviz to plot

text: I think there might even be some exporter in LightGraphs or GraphIO - otherwise that format is really easy to implement yourself

elements.text: I think there might even be some exporter in LightGraphs or GraphIO - otherwise that format is really easy to implement yourself

text: I just played around with NetworkLayouts and Makie.

elements.text: I just played around with NetworkLayouts and Makie.

text: I’ll see if I can get something nice and fast.

elements.text: I’ll see if I can get something nice and fast.

text: I think NetworkLayouts shared a lot of duplicate layout code with GraphPlots

elements.text: I think NetworkLayouts shared a lot of duplicate layout code with GraphPlots

text: good to know. I am playing around with the number of iterations and see if I can get something reasonable fast

elements.text: good to know. I am playing around with the number of iterations and see if I can get something reasonable fast

text: Out of curiosity, what to you expect to get out of plotting a graph this big?
